item.title: By: Piper
item.dc:creator: Piper
item.description: Kick Ass! Now A question, How much of the sound in the videos is real, air vibration, and not just EM interference hitting the microphone magnet? Oh and please remind me not to play with that stuff because it just looks like too much fun right now... *ZORCH* Hehehe...
item.content:encoded:
Kick Ass!
Now A question,
How much of the sound in the videos is real, air vibration, and not just EM interference hitting the microphone magnet?
Oh and please remind me not to play with that stuff because it just looks like too much fun right now…
*ZORCH* Hehehe…

item.content:encoded:
Electricity versus booze

Back off, man. We’re scientists.

…

item.title: By: Steve
item.dc:creator: Steve
item.description: The transformer actually stays quite cool. The driving transistor, on the other hand, gets extremely hot. I have a large passive heatsink (2" x 0.5" x 3") on the IRL530 right now which is more than sufficient when driving the flyback with 5V-12V, but heats up quickly when driven at 24V.
item.content:encoded: The transformer actually stays quite cool. The driving transistor, on the other hand, gets extremely hot. I have a large passive heatsink (2″ x 0.5″ x 3″) on the IRL530 right now which is more than sufficient when driving the flyback with 5V-12V, but heats up quickly when driven at 24V.

item.title: By: Alan
item.dc:creator: Alan
item.description: Cool videos, is there no chance of the transformer self destructing when it arcing for that length of time? Did the transformer get quite hot?
item.content:encoded: Cool videos, is there no chance of the transformer self destructing when it arcing for that length of time? Did the transformer get quite hot?
